docs.abstract: The Quad column on Georgia Tech men's college basketball team, which has given up their cell phones for NCAA tournament; other men's college basketball news noted; photo (M)

headline.main: Yellow Jackets Are Checking Cellphones at the Door

docs.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE -- Georgia Tech has gone low-tech, at least in the postseason. After giving up cellphones and winning three games in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament last week, the Yellow Jackets have again turned in their phones for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

docs.abstract: An M.I.T. fellow is putting together camera kits with balloons and kites to document the damage in the gulf.

headline.main: Taking On the Gulf Oil Spill With Kites and Cameras

docs.lead_paragraph: For over a year, Jeffrey Yoo Warren, a fellow at the Center for Future Civic Media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been messing around with kites, balloons and cameras. The goal is to come up with tools that can be used to take aerial photos without the use of expensive equipment.

docs.abstract: Using copolymers, a university team has developed a way to arrange individual molecules into complex patterns on silicon chips. The research could enable smaller computer chips than current processes allow.
docs.lead_paragraph: Before you read on, take a guess what the image above might be. Go on, I'll wait.

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes One Laptop Per Child project, which aims to give low-cost computers to poor childen, says it is entering partnership with Marvell to develop tablet computers; photo (S)

headline.main: One Laptop Per Child in Tablet Effort

docs.lead_paragraph: The One Laptop Per Child project, which aims to give every child in the world a laptop, announced on Thursday that it was entering a partnership with Marvell, a computer chip and silicon manufacturer. They agreed to work together to develop a new family of tablet computers for the project. The computers will be based on Moby, an existing platform built by Marvell. The partnership hopes to allow Marvell to sell inexpensive tablet computers for education and health care in the United States while helping to reduce the cost of the project's computers for developing countries.

headline.main: Just Give Him 5 Sentences, Not 'War and Peace'

docs.lead_paragraph: Q.When did you first become somebody's boss? A. I was probably 28 or 29 years old and in the jewelry business. I started my career counting diamonds and schlepping gold jewelry around the world.
